revisions.rev:
{{Other people2|Richard O'Sullivan (disambiguation){{!}}Richard O'Sullivan}} {{Infobox person | name = Richard O'Sullivan | image = | imagesize = | caption = O'Sullivan with his ''[[Man About The House]]'' co-star [[Paula Wilcox]]. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1944|5|7|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Chiswick]], [[Middlesex]], [[England]] | yearsactive = 1953â1996 1999, 2006, | height = | birth_name = | othername = | website = | notable role = Robin Tripp
in '''''[[Man About the House]]'''''
and '''''[[Robin's Nest]]''''' }} '''Richard O'Sullivan''' (born 7 May 1944, [[Chiswick]], [[Middlesex]]) is an [[England|English]] [[comedy]] [[actor]] who is probably best known to [[Great Britain|British]] and [[Australia]]n audiences for his role as Robin Tripp in the 1970s sitcoms ''[[Man About the House]]'' (1973â1976) and ''[[Robin's Nest]]'' and as the title character in the period family adventure series ''[[Dick Turpin (TV series)|Dick Turpin]]''. O'Sullivan also starred in ''[[Doctor at Large (TV series)|Doctor at Large]]'', ''[[Doctor in Charge]]'', ''[[Trouble in Mind (film)|Trouble in Mind]]'', ''[[Alcock and Gander]]'' and ''[[Me and My Girl (TV series)|Me and My Girl]]''. ==Early life== Richard O'Sullivan's early education was at St. John the Evangelist's RC primary school in Brentford, Middlesex. After a family holiday in [[Ireland]] as a boy, O'Sullivan returned with a strong Irish accent and was sent to the famous [[Corona Theatre School]] to try to get rid of it, thus starting a distinguished acting career. He appeared in his first film at the age of eight. ==Career== His earliest recognised work was the film ''[[It's Great to Be Young]]'' where he appeared alongside [[John Mills]]. He appeared alongside [[Keith Michell]] and [[Belinda Lee]] in the 1957 opulent swashbuckler, ''[[Dangerous Exile]]'' as [[Louis XVII]], the ten-year-old son of [[Louis XVI]] and [[Marie Antoinette]]. Also during 1957, he co-starred alongside [[Richard Greene]] in two episodes of the television film series ''[[The Adventures of Robin Hood (TV series)|The Adventures of Robin Hood]]'', playing Will Dale in the episode "The Challenge of the Black Knight" and Prince [[Arthur I, Duke of Brittany]]{{Disambiguation needed|date=June 2011}} in the episode "The Double". He also acted in one ''[[Carry On films|Carry On]]'' film, ''[[Carry On Teacher]]'' in the small role of student Robin Stevens. In the early 1960s he appeared in two [[Cliff Richard]] films: ''[[The Young Ones (film)|The Young Ones]]'', and ''[[Wonderful Life (film)|Wonderful Life]]''. O'Sullivan also featured alongside [[Elizabeth Taylor]] in the film ''[[Cleopatra (1963 film)|Cleopatra]]'' as Cleopatra's young brother, [[Ptolemy XIII|Pharaoh Ptolemy XIII]]. For the remainder of the 1960s he was a jobbing actor appearing in such tv series as '[[Dr. Syn:the Scarecrow]]', '[[Emergency Ward 10]]' , '[[Redcap]]', '[[Danger Man]]', [[No Hiding Place]], [[Dixon of Dock Green]]', '[[Strange Report]]' and many more, until in 1971 he was offered the major role of Dr. Lawrence Bingham in [[LWT]] sitcoms ''[[Doctor at Large (TV series)|Doctor at Large]]'' and later ''Doctor in Charge'' both continuations of the sitcom ''Doctor in the House'' which began in 1969. In 1972 he also had a main role in the ITV/[[Thames Television]] comedy ''[[Alcock and Gander]]''. In 1973 he starred as Robin Tripp, a trainee chef, in the flatshare sitcom ''[[Man About the House]]'' written by [[Johnnie Mortimer & Brian Cooke]]. The other regulars were [[Paula Wilcox]] as Chrissie, [[Sally Thomsett]] as Jo, with [[Yootha Joyce]] and [[Brian Murphy (actor)|Brian Murphy]] as Mildred and George Roper, also [[Doug Fisher (actor)|Doug Fisher]] as Larry. The series ended in 1976, he continued playing Robin Tripp in the spin-off sitcom ''[[Robin's Nest]]'', in which Robin sets up a [[restaurant]] with funding from his girlfriend Vicky's ([[Tessa Wyatt]]) father James Nicholls ([[Tony Britton]]). ''Robin's Nest'' was a big success and the first UK sitcom to feature an unmarried couple cohabiting. To tie-in with the series, he wrote a recipe book called ''Man About The Kitchen'', which was published in 1980. He also wrote the ''Robin's Nest'' theme tune, which was arranged by [[Brian Bennett (musician)|Brian Bennett]]. During this period, O'Sullivan also appeared in adverts for [[British Gas plc|British Gas]]. In 1979 he starred in the [[LWT]] children's drama series ''[[Dick Turpin (TV series)|Dick Turpin]]'', in the title role, which ran until 1982, then he played the [[widower]] Simon Harrup in sitcom ''[[Me and My Girl (TV series)|Me and My Girl]]'' broadcast from 1984 to 1988, co-starring [[Tim Brooke-Taylor]] and [[Joan Sanderson]] and also produced by LWT. In the 1990s, his profile decreased although he was never short of work. His final acting role was in a 1996 one-off satire entitled ''Holed'' with [[Tony Robinson]] about a suburban golf club. ==Recent years== O'Sullivan largely retired from public life in 1996. His last appearance on television was as a guest on a 1999 edition of ''[[This Is Your Life]]'' held in honour of his ''Doctor...'' co-star [[George Layton]]. O' Sullivan had himself been the subject of the show in 1974. O'Sullivan suffered a stroke late in 2003. He is now living in [[Brinsworth House]], a [[retirement home]] for actors and performers in England, run by the [[Entertainment Artistes' Benevolent Fund]].http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1107145/Old-Man-About-The-House-Frail-70s-heart-throb-Richard-OSullivan-looks-unrecognisable.html In 2006, O'Sullivan recorded commentary for the DVD release of ''[[Carry On Teacher]]''. == Television roles == {| class="wikitable" !
